dialogues.text: (awkward) Hi Julia...

dialogues.text: CRACK WACKER! I don’t think they meant to...I think they messed up and killed him and now they’re stuck looking for it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What about after, in the car. What‘d he say?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Nothing! Where were you clowns?

dialogues.speaker: CONEY
dialogues.text: L’s right. We were grilling him. He clammed up. Told us to leave it alone  Pink Revisions 40.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What about at the hospital? Coney looks to Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (verbatim - fast) He said: ‘no,ah shit Brooklyn she’s in trouble, played outta my league shoulda... (quieter) Said: “hey Brooklyn you’re no freak okay...?” (beat) He was saying something else at the end... (almost says ‘Formosa’ ) ---I don’t know, I couldn’t hear him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Some fuckin’ riddle. Jesus H.

dialogues.speaker: CONEY
dialogues.text: Whatever he found, somebody with pull wants it. Those weren’t just beat cops at his place. It was suits. Division guys.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Mob thing maybe? Bustamante’s crew has been getting pushy with Frank’s pals I hear. Lionel shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Maybe...Frank did side-work for them since we were all at the Home. But he never got in deep. And he'd have never played it this way with made guys. This felt different. I don’t think he saw this coming. A silence. All at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna say this: I loved the guy. When we were in that fucking hell hole he saw something in us and threw us a line...taught us how to operate. But he never cut us in all the way. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revisions 41.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He played his own games and I’m not gonna stick my nose around his dead cards and risk ending up on a slab for it. (beat) I say we got bills to pay and we better get at it. Coney and Danny nod.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: We owe him more’n that, T.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well you figure out what the fuck it was all about, let us know. Meantime, I’m finishing up on the rabbi’s wife. She’s banging a butcher who ain’t kosher so I think he’s really gonna give her the boot this time and that’s gonna be the last of that ride. I want Gil sitting on the Gunderson fraud thing...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I’m on that.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I want Gil on it...When we bust him the insurance company might want us in there to show the pictures to his lawyer and I wanna make a good impression and Frank ain’t here to cover for you.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Fraud fag!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Like I said. Gil, you’re on it. Danny’11 back me on nights and Lionel you pick up the car slack for him until something else comes in. Lionel stares at Tony. So this is how it’s going to be. TONY (cont'd) (CONT'D) It’s cold. There’1ll be a lot of calls and we need that business. Lionel shrugs, his mind still on Minna.  35 Pink Revisions 42.

dialogues.speaker: FINGERS PULLING THE THREAD
dialogues.text: LIONEL fiddles and twitches sitting at a desk by the phon He has fixed up the office -- immaculate...compulsively ordered. He stares at... “FRANK MINNA” stenciled on the frosted glass door

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Frank Frankady Franko. Minnow Man. “HEAD INVESTIGATOR” LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) Invest-ahead. RING! Phone. LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) L&L. (beat) We have cars available, where would you... Chevy, ma’m. Yes ma’m, this year’s model, where would you... New leather interior, yes. No it smells nice. 247 DeKalb at 2:30. Thank you. Hangs up. He writes down words, mind turning NOTES: colored girl, committee, Horowitz, report, Hamilto signature, father club, one week.

dialogues.speaker: RING
dialogues.text: LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) L&L Agency.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Tony Vermonte in?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: He’s out on a case, how can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Who am I speaking to? Feels it coming and puts the phone on his chest.  36 37 38 Pink Revisions 43.

dialogues.speaker: ASSROG
dialogues.text: (back in the phone) Lionel Essrog, associate invest-- The phone clicks and goes dead. He stares at it a beat an hangs it up slowly. Looks back at the notes. LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) (intoning) ColoredBroadCommitteeHorowitzRepor tHamiltonSignatureFatherClub. Week. From.Thursday. I AIN’T WEAK, I’m THIRSTY! He writes: FORMOSA Then: FORMOSAS Then: FOR MOSA Then: FORM OSA Then: FORMO SA LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) (frustrated)

dialogues.speaker: FORM ASS, BAILEY
dialogues.text: He pops fresh gum, jumps up and goes into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pictures of Frank and the guys. Licenses. Frank’s BLACK TRENCHCOAT. He puts on the coat and MINNA’S HAT, sits in Frank's chair and stares.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Formosa. For-mo-sa-sa-sa-saaaah. He starts rubbing his temples and things SLOW DOWN...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HARLEM SIDE STREET / QUEENS STREET- DAY
dialogues.text: FRANK’S FACE LOOKING AT HIM AS THE CAR DOOR CLOSES FRANK REACHING OUT TO THEM AS THEY WHIP BY...

dialogues.speaker: BANG
dialogues.text: INT. L&L OFFICE - FRANK’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS 38

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hello?  Pink Revisions 44,

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (popping up)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ...through the glass. Thought I was seeing a ghost. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Spinning. You back already?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nah, a round trip. Gotta go back in a bit. Lionel nods, staring into space. DANNY (cont’d) (CONT'D) You alright?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (tortured) I shouldn’ta let him get in that car.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He told you to tail him.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I knew it was going bad. I felt it. Felt the pelt! I blew it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hey, it wasn’t you pushing Frank into a fancy lifestyle he couldn’t afford. He was happy as a clam in that ‘drafty beach shack’. He was playing out on a limb to get her heel outta his ass. (off Lionel’s silence) Anyway...I had a Sergeant during the Bulge...He told me “Sometimes you do everything you’re supposed to and it still goes to shit.” It ain’t on you, bud.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thanks, Danny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Any calls?  39 40 4l Pink Revisions 45.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: What? Oh yeah...shit. What time is it? Gotta pickup at 2:30. CLOCK: 2:15 He jumps up and takes Minna’s coat and hat off, grabs the pea coat and heads to the door. LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) IF! Hey. You ever hear Frank say anything about “Formosa”?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What like the Jap island? (thinks) Nope. He was wounded and out before that. Lionel shrugs and starts out again. DANNY (cont’d) (CONT'D) You know there’s that joint Formosa in mid-town. I tried to take Linda there to hear Chet Baker once. Couldn’t get in. INT. LIONEL’S CAR #2 - DRIVING - DAY 39 He has an old blue-hair in the back. He drops her off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His car slides up on a club marquee. “THE FORMOSA”. INT. FORMOSA LOUNGE - DAY 4l 50’s supper club. Classy. Lionel comes in and looks aroun It’s afternoon empty. Latin guys setting the floor tables There’s a HOSTESS cleaning up candles from tables BARTENDER comes over as Lionel eases onto a stool.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Music’s at seven.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Can I get an early one? Whiskey ginger.  Pink Revisions 46. Bartender nods. Lionel pulls a bill and a matchbook out o his pocket, puts them on the bar. Takes Minna’s detective license out of his coat. LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) Say pal, you in here regular?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Most of my life.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You know a guy named Minna? Frank. That’s him. The bartender looks a beat. Shakes his head

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Everybody looks like everybody to me. But I don’t think so. She’s good with faces. The HOSTESS slides up, overhearing, and indicates to let her see the photo. Studies it then shakes her head but takes in Lionel: kinda cute. She smiles

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: Got a light? Lionel opens the matchbook. Lights one and starts to hold it for her as she leans -- then blows it out. Lights another one, blows it out as she leans again. Her eyebrow raise...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Sorry... Fast now, lights a third, trying to keep it together. Compulsively blows it out.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: (rolls her eyes) Jeez, forget I asked. And she’s gone. Lionel doesn’t even sigh. This is his isolation and he’s used to it. The bartender is laughing though...

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You got something against blondes?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Nah, it’s...it has to sound right or I can’t stop doing it.  42 43 Pink Revisions 47. He lights two more matches and on the last one he’s good.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Must be inconvenient.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Buddy, you don’t know the half of it. Starts to pocket the matches and change...

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: That uptown shit’s the real deal, huh? You get up there much? Lionel stops -- no idea what he’s talking about. The guy points at the matchbook BARTENDER (cont’d) (CONT'D) King Rooster. Lionel turns the matchbook over. A ROOSTER WITH A CROWN O A RED BACKGROUND. LIONEL -- staring. Where’d he get this? Opens it. “B.A. - 2:30” written in a familiar hand. Realizes...It w in Minna’s pants.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know it.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Jazz joint in Harlem. Lucky’s is a good time too but the all the guys playing Hard are at the Rooster. LIONEL -- “a jook joint in Harlem”. He’s moving. INT. LIONEL’S CAR #2 / EXT. HARLEM SIDE STREET - DAY 42 He drives along the block where Minna’s mysterious meetin took place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A RED NEON SIGN WITH THE CROWNED ROOSTER ON IT. Lionel pulls up.  44 Pink Revisions 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small dark Harlem joint. Bar, tables and a little space for the band in a paneled corner that’s hardly even a stage. Black bartender setting up. THREE BLACK GUYS at a back table talking low. One with his back to the bar. LIONEL enters and quick looks check him out. One guy, 50’ very dark black skin, looks at Lionel in the mirror long and hard, watchful.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: We ain’t open yet.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Can I get an early one? I’m freezing here. Whiskey neat. He slaps a bill up. The bartender’11l take that. LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) (fishing) Say, you the manager?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: I look like the manager?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Who's playing tonight?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: (at the THREE GUYS) Hey, Billy... The DARK-SKINNED GUY with his back to the bar looks over. Lionel meets eyes with him in the mirror behind the bar. BARTENDER (cont’d) (CONT'D) Who's on tonight?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Mr Big Shot. His eyes locked on Lionel, he puts a cigarette in his mou with his left hand and then using the same hand to snap open a lighter and light it...highlighting that his RIGHT ARM HANGS LIMP AND USELESS. Lionel still staring. Does he know that face?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: I hope they don’t think they drinking free. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 46 47 Pink Revisions 49.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Lionel re poster) You caught this cat? I seen cool. This brother rewriting cool.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Catch em! Coolie cat! He tries to make it seem like a sneeze. He’s getting excited and that winds up his tics. He’s got to get out. LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) Catch him another time. If!

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Don’t wait long. Them French girls keep loving him up he’s gonna move over there for good, you know what I’m saying? But Lionel’s out the door and we CUT TO: INT. LIONEL’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 45 A RECORD SPINNING, a standard playing, sad but soothing. Camera pans over to find LIONEL in a chair by the radiato with a joint. His head is moving as though he can’t get a kink out of his neck. Or can’t shake his brain. A CAT, comes over and climbs up in his lap. He pets her a this contact seems to calm him as he looks out the window at the lights on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s cold and clear. Lionel’s got a coffee. People are hustling for the subway. Lionel comes past a telephone pole close to camera, flick his eyes at the flyers on it and EXITS... PIECES OF PAPER posted to the pole rustle in the cold... ..-and Lionel comes back into frame, looking closer at on of the flyers, reading:

dialogues.speaker: COME TO A PUBLIC HEARING ON PROPOSED
dialogues.text: 48 Pink Revisions 50.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON HOUSING PLAN
dialogues.text: Sponsored by: Committee against Racial Discrimination in Housing HAMILTON. COMMITTEE. Lionel takes it down and continues o to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel enters Danny’s reading the paper. Tony’s on the phone, pissed...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Well, Christ, Coney, did you get the shot or not?...doing what?...Getting the paper ain’t worth shit! The fuck does that have to do with his back?... Bending over, my ass, we gotta have him lifting the lawnmower out the car or playing tennis or spinning around the room with some broad sittin’ up on his tentpole and his arms out wide. I don’t care so long as it involves his back!...I know he’s fakin’ all the time, that’s why he’s won three claims! Wait him out or set him up!... I know it’s cold, that’s why they call it winter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. Sees Lionel looking at him. That was his case. TONY (cont'd) (CONT'D) I’m giving him the rest of the week.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (not looking up) If the guy lifted a cow into a truck, Coney’d still miss the shot. He still can’t remember to wind the film. Thinks it’s a Tommy- gun. I tell him ‘click-advance- click-advance”...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Can it. I’m giving it a week. Lionel goes to hang up his coat. Phone rings. Tony grabs it...  Pink Revisions 51. TONY (cont'd) (CONT'D) Gimme a break, will ya Gil-- wha? Excuse me, yeah, L&L...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (to Danny) We got pickups?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nobody ever needs a ride on Tuesday, you notice that? Never. Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: ...Speaking... (beat - his eyes flick to the guys) Yeah fine... (writing) .».-yeah I got it. He hangs up and puts the number in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Job?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Nah. For me.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Don’t go getting mysterious on us, T. You ain’t no Minna.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yet! I gotta get a prescription for my mother, clambrain. You need all the details? I’m going for coffee, you want?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Cream and sugar. Tony makes a pansy flick with his wrist, throws on his scarf and hustles out.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Hey, D... You up for something?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Sit on a joint for me.  Pink Revisions 52.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: For you? Lionel tosses him the matchbook.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Club up in Harlem. I think Frank was there that day or the day before...it was in his pants, almost full. Fullsie Pants!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Maybe he stopped in for a book of matches. LIONEL glances out the window as they talk and sees... TONY, across the street outside the coffee shop stopping the payphone.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: In the room he was talking about a girl, a colored chick. Something she knew had em pretty unhappy, wondering who else knew. Frank said her father is a busted up vet who runs a club...this joint is three blocks from that meet.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You went there?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (nods ) Manager is a guy named Billy with a bum arm. LIONEL POV: Tony pulls the number he wrote down and dials

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: So what am I supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Get in there see if you can get her name out of him. Do your liquor board bit. You got that ID still? Lick Broader!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (laughs at that one) Yeah, that’s what she said. I got the ID. That’s it, get her name?  49 50 Pink Revisions 53. LIONEL’S POV: Tony is talking to someone and making notes

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Well if you got nothing better to do... sit on it a while, see if she shows.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: If a colored chick shows up to a jazz joint? Lemme make a prediction...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: No, I'm working another angle. We'll pin her down. LIONEL’S POV: Tony on his way back.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Okay but tell me something... What are we doing this for?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Cause he’d a done it for us.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Right. It’s fuckin’ cold for a sit.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Take the Blue ride, heater’1l roast you like a brisket. Bet on the bris!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You’re a rabbi too now, huh? They both laugh. INT. LIONEL’S CAR - DAY 49 He drifts through Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel crosses the street heading for a nondescript offic building. Checks the address and enters.  51 52 Pink Revisions 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel finds a door with just a number on it. Checks his info again, takes out a piece of gum, folds it exactly in half and pops it in his mouth and then enters into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An open space with desks pushed up against one another. L budget informality. A few private offices with doors at t far end and right in front by the door... Lionel enters and goes to close the door but has to re-op it and close it twice more to make it sound right. He’s good at stakeouts, not at this part. HIS EYES flick around... People busy at work on phones, typing, filling out forms, conferring with each other. A few middle-aged Jewish men and women, and, Lionel immediately notices, FOUR YOUNG BLACK WOMEN, working in different parts of the room: one typing, one walking papers back to one of the offices... One at a reception desk, looking up at Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (pretends it’s a sneeze) If!

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (BETTY)
dialogues.text: Bless you.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (BETTY)
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m here to see Mildred?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (BETTY)
dialogues.text: Mildred? There’s nobody by that name here.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I think it was Mildred...

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (BETTY)
dialogues.text: Myrna...? She points at an older Jewish lady.  Pink Revisions 55.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Myrna bird. (covers) No I believe she was a colored girl.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (BETTY)
dialogues.text: Josephine or Laura? She points at each as she says their names and Lionel mak note of their faces.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: No I’m sure it was Mildred. She spoke to me on the phone about my application. What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (BETTY)
dialogues.text: Betty. What sort of application.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: My vendor’s license. Blank stare LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) Is this not the licensing office?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (BETTY)
dialogues.text: It’s the Committee on Racial Discrimination in Housing.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Then you can’t very well help me sell hot dogs can you! (laughs too loud) I’m sorry to have bothered you. He tips his hat and starts to head out the door. Ona hunch turns back and takes a flyer... LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) Is Mr. Horowitz in by any chance?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (BETTY)
dialogues.text: You mean Mrs. Horowitz?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Either one’1l do.  53 54-55 Pink Revisions 56.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (BETTY)
dialogues.text: (really confused now) She’s in the back...oh there she is... They look and see Gabby Horowitz, director of the Committee, just stepping from her office with LAURA, one the black girls. They see Betty pointing and look up. Lionel waves and points as though to say “I‘’1ll see you outside” and quickly exits... Gabby and LAURA look at each other. Who the hell was that INT. LIONEL’S CAR/EXT. HOUSING COMMITTEE OFFICE - DAY 53

dialogues.speaker: A CAMERA LENS REFLECTING THE OLD INDUSTRIAL BUILDING
dialogues.text: Lionel sits in the car across the street and checks the focus. PLUCKS AT HIS CUFF. Looks through the lens and perks up THROUGH THE CAMERA we see... LAURA emerge, STRIKINGLY PRETTY with LIGHT BROWN SKIN; CLICK. CLICK. LIONEL KEEPS WATCHING, muttering to himself.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Horse-a-whip, Whore-a-witch, Horowitz. He watches her walk away the flicks back to the door A BUNCH OF PEOPLE FROM THE OFFICE, including Horowitz and THE OTHER THREE BLACK GIRLS. CLICK. CLICK. CLICK. He’s popping off shots of them all expertly, like a marksman. This he’s good at. They’re all separating and he has to make a decision and he follows Horowitz... She steps to the curb and hails a CAB. LIONEL starts his car.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT 54-55
dialogues.text: 56 57 58 Pink Revisions 57. INT. LIONEL’S CAR/EXT. SEEDY STREET - FLOPHOUSE APT - DUS THROUGH LIONEL’S WINDSHIELD...as he follows the cab. It cruises slowly onto a seedy street...and stops at a flophouse apartment building next to the elevated train tracks, where Horowitz gets out and hurries to the buzzer IN LIONEL’s CAMERA: She rings and waits but no response. She steps back and looks up at... A LIGHTED WINDOW all the way up on the 5th floor. She rings again then pulls out a flyer like the one Lione saw, writes a note on it and stuffs it in a box, then quickly gets back in the cab and takes off. LIONEL gets out and goes over to look at the name on the box: 502. Just the number and the flyer went through the slot. Dead end.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE PAPER, SWISHING IN LIQUID
dialogues.text: A picture emerges... the girl named LAURA. Very beautiful Lionel pulls it out of the tray and stares at it, then le it dry with the others already printed.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Holy shit, what happened?! Lionel rushes out into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DANNY stands slumped against the door frame with TONY rushing to support him. DANNY HAS BEEN BEATEN UP. He is very shaken, out of breath. Tony moves Danny to a chair and loosens his tie. Danny motions that he needs a drink and CONEY quickly pou him a shot from a bottle in a desk. Danny downs it with a shaky hand.  59 Pink Revisions 58.

dialogues.speaker: CONEY
dialogues.text: Who was it, D?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Couple of em. One was a giant.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: A fuckin’ giant, I’m telling you. Biggest guy I ever saw. Coney and Lionel look at each other, knowing. DANNY (cont’d) (CONT'D) Worked me over good. Smashed up the camera.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: They say anything?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, “Stay outta Minna’s garbage. Tell your crew the same.” Had a big nasty knife on my throat for that part. That sits like a bomb for a second. Tony’s jaw tenses.

dialogues.speaker: CONEY
dialogues.text: Son of a... Danny reaches into his pocket...

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (to LIONEL) Didn’t get this though...assholes. Tosses Lionel a ROLL OF FILM.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: ...the fuck is that? What are you two into? Danny looks at Lionel...and we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RED LIGHT of the dark room goes out. CONEY emerges wi some still wet photos: Danny’s roll...  Pink Revisions 59. Danny is cleaned up a little, butterfly bandage over his swelling shiner, holding ice to his lip.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: .-.-So it definitely ain’t Bustamante’s boys...but it’s still mud. Lionel grabs the photos from Coney. He takes three of his own photos, one of each of the young black women, and lay them out on a desk to compare with Danny’s Danny looks over his shoulder, can’t help being curious. Lionel starts to flip through them.... DANNY’S PHOTOS: - The outside of the King Rooster club - The guy, BILLY, emerging from the club - Aman in a hat, face unseen, asking Billy for a light - Over the man’s shoulder on Billy looking away

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Forget all that, she didn’t show up until later...tail end of the roll. He grabs a few photos off the stack and moves them to the back... - A black woman entering the club but too much from the back Danny flips that one back... DANNY (cont’d) (CONT'D) Here...they came out together. - BILLY and the girl named LAURA from the office talking - LAURA kissing BILLY on the cheek as they part LIONEL compares these to his own and quickly finds the match.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Match me, Bailey! That’s it. She’s the one. Her name was Laura.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Laura Rose then maybe. That’s Billy Rose. If he’s her father...  Pink Revisions 60.

dialogues.speaker: CONEY
dialogues.text: How the hell you know that?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (ignores him) You tailed her?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Didn’t have to...she lives right next to the club on the corner. They musta made me earlier. Soon as I got out the car to follow her they were on me... He stops. It really shook him up. Lionel is excited though. Tony’s paying attention.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I’m telling you this is the broad Frank was tailing.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Okay, I’m with you but it’s still pretty thin.

dialogues.speaker: CONEY
dialogues.text: Skeletal.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: We only just started! They look at each other for a beat. Tony seems to be calculating something. His attitude has changed.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Whatever they want so bad’s gotta be worth something, right? I’1l tell you what, Freakshow, me and Gil’1ll stay on the money work, keep us floating...you and Danny keep sniffing it and we’ll see where we get.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I ain’t looking to make a deal with these fucks but yeah, okay.

dialogues.speaker: CONEY
dialogues.text: Whatever. Hell yeah, I hope those mugs poke around again. I’1l have something for em. Danny stares at the floor.  Pink Revisions 61.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Whaddya say, D?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Fellas, I loved the guy but...I mean I’1ll handle the cars, hustle some domestic shit, you know, but I got Linda and... He can’t say more, doesn’t have to.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Sure, Danny. Right thing.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No doubt. Get on home, get a steak on that eye.

dialogues.speaker: CONEY
dialogues.text: C’mon, I’1l give you a lift. They leave. Tony and Lionel measure each other.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Look all I’m saying...maybe we can get something outta it, for Julia Maybe...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: For Julia? She can go twist.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Okay whatever. But don’t go holding out on shit with me though. We work together, okay Lionel? I'll take anything we can scratch up to Mr. Capodanno and see what those boys know. We pin it on someone, we’ll square accounts. My word on it. Lionel looks at him and nods, then gets up. TONY (cont'd) (CONT'D) You wanna get a beer?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Nah, I’m going home. I’1l see ya later. Tony stares at him a beat then nods at him and leaves. Lionel stares at the photo of Laura and as we push in on her image we CUT TO:  60 61 62 63 64 Pink Revisions 62. EXT. LAURA’S BUILDING - MORNING 60 A passerby crosses the street in the cold passing through small PARK where we find: LIONEL, sipping coffee, twitchi a little and mumbling to himself. He seems happier when he’s alone, less anxious about his tics. Almost seems to enjoy turning words over...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Laura Rose. Rose is a rose is a rose... Larosa! And then he sees...LAURA comes out of her building, and he’s out and moving to follow her... She walks along in the cold, LIONEL sliding into view behind her as she makes her way to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura heads down the steps...Lionel follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura boards the train and moves toward an empty seat onl to have a WHITE GUY move his bag onto the seat and stare her as the train begins to move. She stares at the man with no expression and he back at her, daring her. She turns her back to him leans against a pole, facing direct at LIONEL, which makes him feel a tic coming that he comically struggles to suppress. She takes a book from he bag, some sort of textbook and begins to read, studying a with this he turns away to release a tic and shout. A WOM WITH A SMALL GIRL reacts to this and moves the child away from him. This makes Laura look up over her book for a moment, just as he turns back around and they meet each others gaze fo just a second. She is composed and lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEOPLE GETTING OFF AND ON...More of them white now. Laura is seated but she sees an older white woman coming on wit a cane and gets up to give her the seat. The woman sits without acknowledging Laura. As if she hadn’t been there in the first place.  65 Pink Revisions 63. The boarding crowd pushes Lionel further in and he finds himself standing right next to her as the train starts up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura walks down a block with Lionel tailing behind. The neighborhood is edgy, run down, with many boarded up row houses, uncollected trash and abandoned furnishings. LAURA goes up a stoop and rings a bell. A BLACK LADY answers, wary. Laura talks for a moment and removes some papers from her bag, handing them to the woman. The woman glances at them, nods and closes the door. ANOTHER DOOR. She buzzes. A FACE IN THE SECOND FLOOR WINDOW... a wave. ANOTHER BLACK LADY smiles and hands Laura a sheaf of the same forms and they talk. Lionel can see that the woman i indignant and that Laura is TAKING NOTES. ANOTHER DOOR...this building so bombed out it looks abandoned but AN OLD BLACK MAN WRAPPED IN A BLANKET OPENS and this time Laura goes inside. Lionel glimpses her in the window of the first floor. He pulls some small BINOCULARS out of his pocket, checks around then looks through them... BINOCULAR POV: through the window, LAURA talks with the OLD MAN. It’s obviously freezing in there. She takes out papers and sits with him, asking questions and writing hi answers into the forms. LIONEL turns around for a closer look at a rowhouse behin him, its front door and second story windows boarded up. looks up AT THE FRONT DOOR A SIGN: CONDEMNED: PROPERTY OF: BELMONT DEVELOPERS... A SOUND SURPRISES HIM and he jumps. To his surprise a WOMAN WITH TWO KIDS COME OUT from the garden level door under the stoop. He thought it was abandoned but clearly there are people squatting here. The WOMAN eyes him fearfully and hustles her kids away.  66 67 68 Pink Revisions 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON: A PUDDLE OF WATER. Stark trees, fire escapes & sky reflected in it as LAURA steps across it, rippling th surface and we tilt up to find LIONEL tailing her. He watches as she heads for a nondescript storefront/office: Inwood Residential Services. She goes the door and tries it but it’s locked. She turns and face the street, clearly exasperated as a CAR pulls up and GAB gets out of the driver side. She and Laura confer and Laura moves to get in the car. LIONEL spots a cab and hails it but hustles over to the storefront for a quick look at the sign on the door: “INWOOD: Your Happy Home is Our Business!”. HOURS: 9-5 Lionel looks at his watch: 3:21 Should be open. But he hustles to his cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab pulls over on the shoulder, a distance from the other car which is pulled up under an overpass, with haza lights on. Lionel’s POV: the women getting out.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Get out and pop your hood and check the oil.

dialogues.speaker: CABBIE
dialogues.text: Buddy, come on...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Keep the meter going. He lifts his binoculars as the cabbie grudgingly complies Lionel’s POV: Gabby shading her eyes, looking up at... LAURA, who has climbed up the slope to the overpass above and is lowering a tape measure. We PAN DOWN with the tape measure to Gabby, who records t height of the overpass. ON LIONEL: no idea what they’re doing. SMASH CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: OMIT 68
dialogues.text: 69 Pink Revisions 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FACES IN A BUZZING SEATED CROWD as we tilt up to see GABB & LAURA, hustling down the center aisle of a packed auditorium to where their staff members hold seats near a standing mic. A group of men at two long tables on stage with mics. Amo the men, THE MAYOR and LIEBERMAN. LIONEL enters in the back and takes in the scene. He note a guy in the back rows with ‘PRESS’ cards in his hat band and slides into a seat behind him. Lionel leans over his shoulder and takes out his notebook to play at being a fellow reporter

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: This ain’t my beat. What’s the story?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (JACOB GLEASON)
dialogues.text: Stories of injustice and despair, nodding heads and assurances, back to business as usual. The American Way. Although this one could make it interesting. He indicates GABBY down the aisle conferring with Laura. sees Gabby catch sight of: a TALL THIN MAN entering and taking his seat. Slightly frayed but hawk-like eyes focus intently on the proceedings. He nods at Gabby. Lionel deftly slips one of the reporter’s cards from his hatband and pockets it with practiced ease. A man onstage kicks things off. WILLIAM LIEBERMAN, one of Moses Randolph’s sub-bosses.

dialogues.speaker: LIEBERMAN
dialogues.text: We'll commence this public comment. State your name, address and affiliation please. I’m William Lieberman, Mayor’s Commission on Slum Clearance, resident of E.65th St, Manhattan

dialogues.speaker: LADY AT MICROPHONE
dialogues.text: Cindy Fleming, homemaker, Yonkers...but formerly East Tremont. My family was forced to move when they seized our building for the Bronx Expressway, and I want people to know that--  Pink Revisions 66. He cuts her off and speaks to Gabby.

dialogues.speaker: LIEBERMAN
dialogues.text: Mrs. Horowitz, you may not hijack these proceedings to air out old complaints against...

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: (rapidly, following rule) Gabby Horowitz-Committee on Racial Discrimination in Housing- 552 Clinton Ave, BROOKLYN. I thought this was a community hearing?

dialogues.speaker: LIEBERMAN
dialogues.text: On housing not highways... Lionel focuses on him... his VOICE familiar...

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: You’re making the same promises to Ft Greene that you made in Tremont, where your so-called ‘relocation services’ vanished into thin air and left families like the Flemings utterly adrift. People have a right to know what they’re in for! Lionel watches LAURA, slipping Gabby notes.

dialogues.speaker: LIEBERMAN
dialogues.text: We are totally committed to the welfare of families displaced by necessary community improvement programs. The past has been instructive and our new contractors will ensure ALL find adequate homes... As she speaks MOSES RANDOLPH enters late from the side, tuning in and already impatient. Gabby notes his arrival.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: This isn’t Long Island you know... It’s not just a blank canvas you can paint on anywhere you like. There are people here, established communities. Randolph shoots an impatient look at the Mayor as he SITS...The Mayor snaps up obediently...  Pink Revisions 67.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: I hope you all know my name. I’m the Mayor, newly residing at Gracie Mansion, Manhattan. (a few laughs) Mrs Horowitz, thank you for work and your passion. Surely we can all agree that even in a City as great as ours we have slums. And that a slum is not something to romanticize or preserve. You tear it down and improve quality of--

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: A neighborhood is not a slum because poor people and minorities live there, Mr. Mayor. East Tremont wasn’t a slum, Third Avenue wasn’t a slum and Fort Greene is not a slum either, these are working class communities. (to Randolph) Your developers are making it a slum! This brings Randolph lunging forward.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: That is unsubstantiated, unmitigated bunk! Laura hands her reams of paper which she holds aloft...

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: We have it on paper, we have twenty people here tonight and scores behind them who can testify to a scandalous fraud under way...which way would you like it first? Randolph slaps the table with his flat palm violently, rising out of his chair and overlapping her.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: We are embarking on the most ambitious slum clearance program in American history Mrs. Horowitz and you are gumming it up with your molasses! A Niagra of molasses! Suddenly a voice in the audience shouts:  Pink Revisions 68.

dialogues.speaker: MAKE HIM SAY HIS NAME
dialogues.text: Heads turn. Lionel turns. Concern on Gabby’s face. ANGLE ON: THE TALL THIN MAN, still seated.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (PAUL)
dialogues.text: Name and place of residence, like everyone else! A smattering of applause. The energy is winding Lionel up his arm and head jerk spasmodically. RANDOLPH stares out seeking the source of the voice, eyes narrowing, glaring. He crosses his arms defiantly. He loo at the Mayor: “Handle it.” The MAYOR rises.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Now see here, we all know perfectly well who this is... Mo Randolph is one our greatest public servants. He’s a living legend.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (PAUL)
dialogues.text: Name and residence like everybody else! The audience cheers, really behind it now. Some start to call out “Make him say it! Make him say it!” Gabby smiles discreetly. Lionel yelps-

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Every Chevy shelf! Randolph glares at the Mayor who is starting to sweat.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: (trying to stay light) He’s led the Parks Department for over 30 years...he’s Commissioner of Construction, well, he’s got too many jobs to name! (knowing laughter) And he lives right across the street from me on East 88th, now let’s stick to-- Cat calls... a few yells...many people rising to their fe The MAN rises to his feet now, raging..  70 Pink Revisions 69.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (PAUL)
dialogues.text: Make him say it!!

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: See here now, if we can’t keep this civil we’ll have to ask you to...

dialogues.speaker: SAY IT
dialogues.text: The crowd chants “Say it!” This is too much for Lionel... Lieberman nods to some plainclothes SECURITY MEN along th sides of the room who quickly descend on the MAN. And now the crowd is on its feet indignant. As they sweep behind LIONEL with the MAN (Paul) it’s too much him and he leaps up shrieking

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Address him by name, Bailey! So they grab him too and hustle him out with the MAN (Pau LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) Say it, Hammy Ham House Heads!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel and the MAN shrug off the final SHOVES of the cops and stand looking at each other in the street. THE MAN is neatly dressed but his clothes are visibly wor and shabby. Gaunt and graying, he could be taken for a bu but his eyes are fierce and sharp, hawkish. We will come know him as Paul. He regards Lionel with curiosity...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: ‘Hammy Ham House Head’, huh? That’s good. I’1l have to remember that one.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (still ticcing) IF! sorry... IF!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s the rub in life alright... ‘if’... ‘if only’...  Pink Revisions 70. He shakes his head and starts to walk away muttering to himself unintelligibly. Lionel stuffs gum, getting under control, calls out

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Hey, hold on... tell me something. That guy Lieberman, he’s in charge of this Hamilton deal?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: In charge? No, he’s not in charge...More in charge than that guy calling himself Mayor but... (laughs, turns away) They all work formosa... CU: Lionel’s face as he barely hears that last word. He runs after Paul and grabs him by the arm... PAUL (cont'd) (CONT'D) Hey...!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You said “Formosa”...what’s that?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What? Let me go! You nuts?!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You said “They’re all working Formosa.” What’s that mean?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What’s ‘formosa’? Let go of me. (realizing) “For Moses.” Jesus. I said they’re working for Moses. Moses Randolph. Lionel realizes: that’s what Frank said to him as he lay dying -- “For Moses”...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Mo Randolph? That guy who came in?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah...‘He who will not speak his name like one of the rabble’. What do you care? Lionel quickly pulls out the reporter’s card.  71 Pink Revisions 71.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Jacob Gleason, the Post. Let me buy you a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m hungry. You can buy me dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul digs in like a guy who eats too rarely. Lionel pops gum and nurses a tea... Paul talks like a firehose...disgorging so much information, even as he chews, that it’s hard to keep up with the thread. Huge pent up frustration venting in urge torrents with hardly a pause between thoughts...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (appalled) The Mayor?! That clown is so green he doesn’t even know what he doesn’t know yet. He’ll be out the door before he even realizes that every person he turns to for advice is on Randolph’s payroll.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I thought he was Commissioner of Parks?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He is.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: But they called him Construction Commissioner.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He’s that too now. They never even had that position until the Feds decided to get in the housing game. It had no defined powers so he defined ‘em and the Feds approved and now how much control of that money has the City got? Zero. He's got it all. You know what ‘eminent domain' means? If he says it's a slum, it goes. He used to have to fight to put his highways and parks where he wanted, now he can go anywhere, tear anything down. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revisions 72.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He can condemn a whole section of the city, evict everyone who lives there and put up what he wants. And he'll go at it with an axe.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: SMACKS AXE. He'll piss too many people off. He’1ll be the most hated man in NY.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, they love him! That’s what makes me so... He flies above it. They revere him.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Because he built the parks! As long as you're the guy who brings people parks, you walk with the angels, you can't lose. The day Rockaway Beach opened, Moses Randolph became a folk hero in this town. But people don't realize how much he hates them. “The Hero of the Public Who Hates People”. There's your headline. And you know who he hates especially? (mouths ‘Negroes’ ) He's going to seize every neighborhood in this city that's not white and turn it over to his hand-picked private Developers.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: So he’s getting rich. Paid off.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Nah, he doesn't want money...he wants control and he brokers money to get it and guard it. Some men aren't satisfied unless they have filet mignon. Moses would be happy with a pastrami sandwich and power. (to a waitress) Can I get a piece of cheesecake? And warm it up. Yeah, I want it warm! (leans in) Half the city is getting a ride on one of his horses. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 Pink Revisions 73.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: $3.5 billion since the war! He cuts people in on one piece of it or another but he's the broker of all of it. (almost to himself, muted) Bridge and Tunnel and now Title 1 ..--for chrissake, he controls every fuckin’ construction job in the city.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: But you said they just created the position...so how...?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, christ...Construction-Parks- Slums...he’s got 14 appointments! That’s all just ink on a glass door, none of it matters, it’s all the BA.

dialogues.speaker: BA
dialogues.text: This actually stops Paul and makes him narrow his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The Borough Authority, jeezus. Where do you come from, Iowa? Call yourself a reporter...on what, the Arts beat? You read Emerson? Lionel shakes his head, which makes him have to jerk it three times hard. Paul observes this...curious... PAUL (cont'd) (CONT'D) Emerson said “an institution is the lengthened shadow of one man”...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headlights of the waiting CAR light up the front of the massive stone face and steps of the edifice where Moses works.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This town is run by the Borough Authority and the Borough Authority is Moses Randolph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73 Pink Revisions 74. As the tall shadowy figure descends the stairs toward the cars his SHADOW THROWS HIGH OVER THE FACE OF THE BUILDING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel walks through the grand marble lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel walks into the huge room carrying a few huge bound volumes of newspapers and sits at a table c.U. - Articles on Moses Randolph. One after another announcing his accomplishments “West River Park Opens”, “Hudson Highway”, “A Grand New Beach for Gotham”, “Bronx Expressway to Liberate Manhattan from Traffic Snarl”. And effusions of Randolph: “Servant of the People”; “A Reformer becomes a Builder: ‘to build is to dream’ says Moses Randolph” PICTURES: the Triborough Bridge under construction. Moses smiling and shaking hands with one Mayor after another: LaGuardia; O’Dwyer; Impellitieri; the new Mayor... Lionel stops on one: “The Men of the B.A.” - a photo show Randolph seated and smiling broadly, surrounded by men in Suits. Their names captioned: William Lieberman, George Spaulding, Tom Brooks... LIONEL FOCUSES ON: William Lieberman. He was the man in the apartment with Minna. The one in charge...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (whispered) Lieberman. Leering man. CLOSE ON: another article...”The Private Life of a Public Man...many of his closest colleagues were surprised to learn he has a brother.” PICTURE: a YOUNGER MOSES RANDOLPH and A MAN WHO LOOKS VER FAMILIAR...both in black tie attire and smiling...Randolp leans affectionately on his brother’s shoulder CAPTION: “Moses Randolph and Paul Randolph: 1927” LIONEL’s FACE: recognizing Paul Randolph as the man he bought dinner for. He takes out his pen-knife and quietly cuts out this phot and pockets it.  74 75 76 77 Pink Revisions 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME CUT: Lionel is handing the box of papers back to a clerk when he sees the clerk’s paper lying open and a sma

dialogues.speaker: HEADLINE
dialogues.text: “BUILDER'S ASSOC TO HONOR Moses Randolph....Plaza Hotel”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black tie crowd. Working class, union bosses, wives...but dressed up and slicked for their one big night. Martini glasses and cigarettes. Union security at the doors to th Banquet with pins on their lapels. LIONEL steps out of elevators behind a few late arrivals who hustle in. Inside beyond the check in table the vast floor of banquet tables and stage can be seen. Not in a t and with no invite he clearly can’t go in the normal way. A BELL, signals the start of the program and people flow back in. Lionel moves across to another door...more to the side, a slides up to the UNION SECURITY APE. He pulls the edge of an envelope from inside his jacket...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Gotta get this to Bill Lieberman. The pea-brain UNION APE knows that name well enough to ha to think... LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) He’s gonna want to see this before Randolph sits back down with him... Too many big names to risk it. The guy waves him in and w begin to hear...

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, settle please and give me your serious attention. Our celebration is made special by tonight’s Guest of Honor...

dialogues.speaker: OMIT 77
dialogues.text: 78 Pink Revisions 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPEAKER (CONT’D) ..-A Brother to our Trade who would rightly be hailed this country’s Master Builder. Or...the ‘Great Dirt Mover’, as he likes to be called! LIONEL: slides into a back corner, waiters flowing in and out past him. He looks left and spots... JACOB GLEASON, the reporter from the public hearing, ina tux. He sees Lionel and thumbs his nose in solidarity. Lionel slides up next to him. Gleason nods, impressed Lionel got in without a tux. He whispers...

dialogues.speaker: GLEASON
dialogues.text: Don’t let em see you take out a notebook. Tonight is: ‘Press: fuggedaboudit’. SPEAKER (CONT’D) We'd have to look to the Caesars and Pharaohs to find men with a scale of vision to compare with his and yet none of it bears his name, so fully does he forbear the credit, allowing the people to say “we built this ourselves.” A great man, a man of history, serving the people of this City for over 25 years...Moses Randolph! A ERUPTION OF APPLAUSE: As Randolph takes the stage. He tries to speak and they won’t let him. Shouting as though for a general after a triumph...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You'd think Patton showed up.

dialogues.speaker: GLEASON
dialogues.text: He pays one and half times union rate as base on all his jobs. They'd pave over their mothers for him. Lionel’s eyes cast around...spotting faces: Lieberman and the others from the papers. POV: in the shadows against a column...Paul. Clutching a large, full envelope. Staring, inscrutable. He snags two rolls from a passing tray, munches one and stuffs the oth into his suit pocket.  Pink Revisions 77. Randolph begins speaking...

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: Tonight, over 300 years since the founding of this great city, we recommit ourselves to the ancient truth...that it is not knowledge but Action...Enterprise...which is the engine and objective of life. Clever men come and go but for every dozen men with a bright idea there is at most one who can execute them. I look around this room and I don’t see a lot of Bright Boys or Goodie Goodie progressives with their paralyzing ideals! (huge laughter) I see men of my tribe. Men who know how to Get Things Done! The Doers who make this country great. And an honor by you is all the affirmation or payment I’1l ever seek. I thank you and celebrate you. Wild applause...the crowd comes to its feet again. LIONEL watches: Randolph descends the stage. He’s mobbed the bosses high and low...all pressing up to pay respects Eventually Moses has to break away. Lionel’s eyes flick to: Paul...realizing that Randolph will not be exiting past him, moves urgently to cross the room toward him. His envelope under his arm, hunting for line to cut Randolph off before he leaves. But the crowd surges and Paul is blocked. RANDOLPH spots Paul though. They LOCK EYES for just a second...Randolph frowns, surprised. But something in Paul’s face makes him pause...something both insistent an pleading. He sees what Paul is holding and his eyes narro weighing. A small nod...a crack opens that Paul sees and almost palpably steps toward...But Randolph’s face seems say ‘Not here.’ LIEBERMAN whispers something to him and with a final look at Paul he turns and is led out the sid exit. Paul’s jaw clenches but his eyes are alight and he hustle for an exit...and LIONEL FOLLOWS...  79 80 81 Pink Revisions 78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIONEL follows Paul and then peeks around a corner to fin Paul pacing in the dark along a nice apartment building, near the edge of the light from the canopied doorway. He’ waiting, not hiding. THE BIG BLACK CAR pulls up...Paul straightens his hat and smooths his jacket as..... RANDOLPH GETS OUT. Paul steps out of the dark, blocking the path to the doorway. RANDOLPH stops and they stand facing each other a BEAM OF LIGHT FROM THE DOORWAY. Lionel leans around the corner to listen and we can see i playing out behind Lionel like a shadow play that we hear bits of. Paul holds THE FOLDER out. RANDOLPH stares at him then sa something and nods and takes the package. They exchange words and begin to argue but then Paul breaks off, relenting. He points at the package. Randolph nods and go inside. Paul stands, staring into the light after his brother, his thin coat blowing around him but his head up high. For a moment he seems straightened up by hope. Then he turns and walks into the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIONEL hustling through the crowd in the cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel on the phone...muffling it a bit...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Jacob Gleason for Laura Rose...hi yourself...nah, I gotta cold...Well where'd she go?...that in Fort Greene? Fart Cream!! (buries it like a sneeze) I‘1l do that...thanks. He’s off...  82 83 84 Pink Revisions 79. INT. LIONEL’S CAR #2/EXT. FORT GREENE STREET/BROWNSTONES Lionel drives down a street looking for an address. Even more desolate and run down than the first place he follow Laura, a once happy lower-middle class neighborhood of brownstones, now ravaged, boarded up windows everywhere. tense atmosphere... Suddenly he spots LAURA coming down a stoop with a young BLACK MAN. He is talking fast, ANGRY. Lionel parks and watches in the rear view mirror as they go up into anothe dilapidated brownstone. Lionel gets out and approaches the stoop. Spies that the ground floor door under the stoop is swinging open. Knock waits, looks around...and enters into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darker inside...gloomy. He can hear voices upstairs. Daylight cutting through in hard shafts. We can see that this was a nice middle class home, but it looks like it’s been strip-mined. An empty space where the fridge should be, fixtures ripped away, nice walls cut open to remove sections of copper pipe, now dripping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel pokes into a bathroom and clicks the light on...it still works, dimly sputtering. Nice tiles broken to get a pipes, sink fixtures gone. He looks at himself in the mirror, watching impassively a his own head TWITCHES and SPASMS mildly.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (to himself) Keep it together, freakshow. He reaches for the vanity mirror and opens it to see what inside only to find... POV: he’s looking clear into the next room. The wall behind the mirror has been opened and pipes stripped out. Then... A BLACK GUY STEPS INTO THE FRAME OUT OF NOWHERE, looking Lionel who jolts and with a yelp steps back into... The ANGRY GUY LAURA was with, now blocking the door.  85 Pink Revisions 80.

dialogues.speaker: ANGRY GUY
dialogues.text: Looking for somethin’?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Scared the hell...HELP, BAILEY! They look round for who he’s calling out to...

dialogues.speaker: ANGRY GUY
dialogues.text: You think you can just walk into people’s homes?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Looking for a friend. Didn’t look like anyone lived down here...

dialogues.speaker: ANGRY GUY
dialogues.text: Oh, someone live here. My momma live here. Least she tryin’ to. Who you with? I hope you with Belmont. Sounds like an angle, so Lionel nods.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Yeah...course. Belmont. Who else, right? He looks back to the other guy...and the FIST IS ALREADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muted sounds of argument and feet. The sharp sound of heels. FADE UP SLOWLY... WOOZY POV: Faces out of focus.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: How hard did you hit him?

dialogues.speaker: ANGRY GUY
dialogues.text: I barely tapped him. Fool slipped and hit his own head! Lionel sits up a little and focuses, his nose slightly bloody  Pink Revisions 81.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: ‘If’ what? I/’11 tell you what ‘if’, you better explain who you are if you want to walk out of-- (pauses) Have I seen you before?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (nods - seizing the angle) Hamilton hearing. I’m a reporter. She glares at the YOUNG MAN. He looks chagrined.

dialogues.speaker: ANGRY GUY
dialogues.text: He the one said he’s with them racketeering sons a bitches! They stole her damn fridge and her copper pipe! What you expect?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel has tissue up his nose as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: First they put up a notice says the house will be condemned. It’s not true but that scares out about half and they sell for cheap. Then they come in and take the nice old family homes and chop em into 4 and rent em up. Folks who don’t leave they harrass...turn the heat off, come in to do repairs and steal copper pipe instead. They re-possessed all the refrigerators, even if people bought them themselves, then resold them out of shopfronts next neighborhood over. City sold em property worth $15 million for $500,000 to take the ‘risk’ of having to build the Federal projects. They haven’t even submitted plans...just milked it until it really is a slum.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Slammer for Slum Lords, Bailey!  Pink Revisions 82.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (bristling) Oh what, you another one that thinks we’re just ‘agitating’... making it up like some Negro propaganda conspiracy...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (stopping her) No, no. Look I got a condition, I say funny things sometimes but I’m not trying to be funny, okay? I’m listening. Where’s everybody go?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Mostly just disappear. Fade away. Go into real slums or other neighborhoods. Some are renting a room in a house they used to own. 200,000 in 2 years just from this part of Brooklyn. Mostly Negro. Latino.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: But Horowitz said they did it in Tremont too.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yeah they did it to a few Jews too but not systematic like this. You know how many parks have been built in this city since he’s been Commissioner? 255. How many of those in Harlem you think? 1. You build a new beach for the ‘people’, but the ones with no cars, the poor ones, the black and brown ones?...how are they going get to the parks and beaches? Public bus. Guess how high they just built the overpasses on the new parkway? One foot too low for a bus to clear. Look forget whether it’s discrimination...the Federal government and the City are being scammed. There’s supposed to be relocation services, company’s got a $2 million dollar contract to handle it but nobody even answers the phone. Call the city, they say these folks are on the list for the new public housing. But then it never gets built.  Pink Revisions 83. They have come to Lionel’s car. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You know more’n any secretary I ever met.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (indignant) Secretary? Who told you that? I’ve got a law degree you know? I’11 pass the Bar first time I sit too. He’s staring at her now...she’s beautiful to him. She catches it and blushes...then sharpens her look, suspicious. LAURA (cont'd) (CONT'D) How are you gonna write about it all when you don’t even take a note?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: “2 million for relocation; bridges a foot too low for buses; 1 out of 255 parks; $15 mil for $500k; 200,000 people in Ft Greene alone”. I never forget anything, believe me. Not a single word. She nods, impressed. He’s strange but he really looks at her and listens. He can’t help it and has to tap her twic on the shoulder. LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) Sorry...I really can’t help it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (softens) It’s okay. Just write about it, okay? What happens to poor people in this city wasn’t news yesterday and it won’t be tomorrow. But you’d think somebody’d care what happens to Brooklyn. It’s only the biggest city on Earth. She sighs and looks away.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Where do you live?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Harlem.  87 Pink Revisions 84.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I can give you a ride. Trains’1l be mobbed. That surprises her but she looks at him and then nods.

dialogues.speaker: ENGINE ALONG WITH THEM.
dialogues.text: INT. LIONEL’S CAR #2 - LATE AFTERNOON INTO NIGHT 87 She puts on the radio and finds a Jazz station as... MONTAGE: Lionel drives them through the city They don’t say much of anything at all but some faster ‘bop’ on the radio activates his tics which he tries to hide which only makes it worse.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Bebob, Bailey in the Metropolitan BOPera House! Shit. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Don’t be sorry, it’s kinda funny.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hang around a little longer. She can see that it weighs on him. Notices the twitching now

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What is all that anyway?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It’s like a piece of my head split off and got a life of its own but then decided to keep joyriding me for kicks. (!) It’s a fucking anarchist. But the flip side is its gotta have everything in its right place, sounding just right. Like I’m talking to you but that piece of my head? It’s worrying that the bills in my wallet aren’t all facing the same direction.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I guess we all got our daily battles, right?  88 89 Pink Revisions 85.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Yeah, fair enough. Kiss her face all night, Bailey! He’s mortified by that one but she laughs hard...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I really am sorry, I don’t mean nothing by it

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It’s alright. Really it’s alright She changes the music to a cool ballad and they drive on, crossing the bridge into Manhattan and on up to Harlem as night falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV: Someone in a car is watching them park INT. LIONEL’S CAR/EXT. KING ROOSTER - CONTINUOUS 89 The exterior of the little club is hopping. People hustli inside, some folks having a smoke. A cool little kid in a full suit and hat on the sidewalk acting like a doorman waves at Laura through the window. Laura points to the building next to the club

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: This is me.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: That keep you up nights?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: My father owns this place. I grew up falling asleep in the back of clubs.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Pretty hopping on a Monday night.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yeah, hottest band in the world, all week. I gotta check on one or two things, but...look, are you really interested...in what I was telling you?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I came looking for you didn’t I?  90 Pink Revisions 86.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: If you want to come in I can give you a lot more. He looks at the club: it’s exactly the kind of scene that spells disaster for him usually. She smiles LAURA (cont'd) (CONT'D) You can’t exactly disturb the peace in a small club with a hot band. She indicates ‘C’mon’. He gives in and they get out into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place is for real. No mid-town mainstream joint. A l of energy...buzz of anticipation over who’s playing...a f white Beat kids from Columbia trying to blend in... Almost immediately it starts to infect Lionel. His head jerks and he pops gum right away...Laura points him at a table against the wall and boots two young cats out of it with one look. She heads for the end of the bar and the cash register, bringing the BARTENDER to her with a look. She clearly has the run of the place... As Lionel sits he takes it all in...sees eyes on him. Coc Minna’s hat back and watches as a WHITE KID comes up nervously to the TRUMPET PLAYER having a drink before his band’s set with his FRENCH GIRLFRIEND and his Piano playe

dialogues.speaker: BEATNIK
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir...? The TRUMPET PLAYER and his friend flick a look up. BEATNIK (cont'd) (CONT'D) Sorry...I’m a trumpet player too and I really admire your tremolo...I just wondered how you developed that?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMPET
dialogues.text: Suckin’ off little white boys like you. Get the fuck outta here... The TRUMPET PLAYER turns back to his laughing friend, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: SO WHAT, Whitey White Suck Stick!  91 Pink Revisions 87. This makes the TRUMPET PLAYER turn in surprise laughing..

dialogues.speaker: TRUMPET
dialogues.text: Whitey White Suck stick! ‘So what’ is right... LIONEL’S POV: Laura drilling the BARTENDER over something to do with the register count. He’s giving her back talk and she’s not having it. She SLAPS THE BAR HARD TWICE, shutting him up and dresses him down. The TRUMPET PLAYER laughs at this and wags his finger at the bartender then takes the stage. Lionel gets up and moves to the end of the bar to get a drink, watching her and meeting her eye...she starts walking toward him and SMILES and it makes things slow do for a second...and then right as she takes the stool next to him...the MUSIC kicks in... A HARD FAST SNARE RIFF: and then it’s ON. It hits Lionel like a shot and he WHOOPS loud...but so do half the joint...and for once he doesn’t seem so weird. Laura laughs and we JUMP CUT INTO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SEQUENCE: Lionel is getting drunk and starting to get totally flipped out on the HARD JAZZ, ticcing and shoutin with abandon, self-consciousness gone because it seems to egg on the band... BILLY ROSE: in the door. A young dude leaning in to whisp to him but Billy’s eyes are LOCKED ON-- LIONEL and LAURA, leaning together drinking and laughing. BILLY whispering back to the guy and indicating... Suddenly the guy is at Laura’s elbow pulling on her and whispering. Lionel is too into the music to notice...he’s on his feet and jerking spasmodically...but LAURA is havi none of it. She knows this guy and is telling him to beat it. SONG ENDS to clapping and shouts. LIONEL hooting and whistling. THE TRUMPET PLAYER is picking up the vibe off Laura and intervenes on the mic....

dialogues.speaker: TRUMPET
dialogues.text: Uh oh, there’s my favorite girl... my sister...  92 93 Pink Revisions 88. Everybody looks over and this makes the GUY back off Laur who shakes his hand off her arm hard. BILLY, his eyes fierce on Lionel and jaw tight. LAURA GRABS a clueless LIONEL and pulls him on the floor dance...TRUMPET PLAYER gets her cue... TRUMPET (cont'd) (CONT'D) One for my Laura Rose.... He slides into the SLOW SAD THEME WE HEARD OVER THE TITLES...and Laura steps up to Lionel, other couples standing with them. LIONEL is still jerking hard, wound up...BILLY is frowning, furious and worried... LAURA puts her hand on LIONEL’s shoulder and pulls in close, looking at his face as if willing him to calm down...AND HE DOES. Slowly her touch settles him, he breathes easier and dances with her, holding still... BILLY whispers urgently, angry to two more YOUNG CATS who nod. They dance slow until the song ends...it can’t last forever. TRUMPET (cont'd) (CONT'D) That’s for Laura... The crowd claps as Lionel stares at her not wanting to le go but she’s seeing something over his shoulder and she touches his face a second and then, annoyed, breaks away...leaving him as the BAND TEES OFF AGAIN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIONEL SPINS and gets SWEPT INTO THE MUSIC AGAIN

dialogues.speaker: JUMP CUT
dialogues.text: HE’S IN A FRENZY. SCATTING AND BOPPING WITH THE BAND, DRUNK and HAPPY. THE PLAYERS ARE DOING A CALL AND RESPONS WITH HIS CRAZY TOURETTIC SHOUTS...

dialogues.speaker: ..-AND THEN SUDDENLY SOMEONE HAS HIM BY THE COLLAR. HE
dialogues.text: TURNS TO LOOK FOR LAURA BUT SHE’S GONE and he is being BU RUSHED OUT THE BACK AND INTO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...where he gets THROWN DOWN HARD. THREE YOUNG GUYS looming over him. One gives him a good kick to the ribs.  94 Pink Revisions 89. LIONEL’S on the ground looking up, woozy and short of breath. BILLY'S THERE...looking down on him. Billy grabs him up b the collar, USING ONLY HIS LEFT ARM...THE RIGHT HANGING LIMP.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You think I don’t know who you work for, cracker?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You got it wrong--Scaredy Cat! Cracker Jack! Blackie Black! This pisses Billy off even more...He hauls Lionel up hard with his one powerful arm.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I made it through Iwo Jima, motherfucker! You think your boss scares me? You tell him I see any you snoops round her again I’11l kill you one at a time, then I’11 mail what he’s lookin’ for to the Post for free! His guys start pulling him off...freaked out a bit. POV: from down the alley around the edge of a corner, someone is watching Billy and his boys over Lionel...and listening... LIONEL’S POV: drunk and blurry, BILLY leaning over BILLY (cont’d) (CONT'D) YOU HEAR ME! I’M GONNA MAIL IT TO

dialogues.speaker: THE POST
dialogues.text: LIONEL’S POV: on his back looking up at fire escape...voices “C’mon Billy...”. His gaze falls sideways into the alley where, blurry, a silhouetted figure seems be watching. In the backlight the edge of a scarf blows, then is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND OF FEET, shuffling. A match...someone snorts and spits. LIONEL’s POV: fading in...woozy....the TRUMPET PLAYER sitting over him, smoking...something in his hand.  95 Pink Revisions 90.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Help...Hep! Hep!

dialogues.speaker: TRUMPET
dialogues.text: (laughs) You was pretty hep in there my man. Lionel is out of control...can’t stop jerking, agonizing. C.U.- In the Trumpet Player’s hand is a pipe...he was prepping a smoke of something...something more than weed. Lionel fixates on it...reaching for it... TRUMPET (cont'd) (CONT'D) Your head need fixin’? Lionel nods. Trumpet hands it to him and lights a match. He leans in, inhales and The FLAME BLOOMS IN LIONEL’s FAC and as a TRUMPET STARTS UP, everything GOES GOLDEN and we FADE INTO....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He’s coming out of the golden fog on the bridge, THE GEOMETRIC PATTERNS OF THE WIRES AND TOWERS ABOVE...he sees... A FIGURE, leaning on the rail...he turns...it’s MINNA. He’s wearing his same old hat, Lionel unconsciously reach for his head but he’s got nothing on it. Minna grins and looks out across the harbor....Lionel follows his gaze... DREAM POV: fog clears over the river and in beams of ligh the TOWERS AND SPANS OF A MASSIVE BRIDGE emerges...Impossibly big, spanning from Brooklyn to the t of Manhattan. Monstrous.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: ...the fuck is that...?

dialogues.speaker: MINNA
dialogues.text: Pyramids on the Nile, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: What's going down, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: MINNA
dialogues.text: Big things. Too big. (sad, wistful) Shoulda kept it under my hat.  96 Pink Revisions 91. He taps his temple and smiles, sad...Lionel realizes Minn no longer has the HAT on...it’s back on Lionel, confused. He follows Minna’s gaze out to the East. DREAM POV: an ALMOST MAGICAL VIEW OF BROOKLYN, all the wa to the sea.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Jesus, this city has no end. They’re gonna cover the world with it.

dialogues.speaker: MINNA
dialogues.text: Nah, Brooklyn's big, but there’s things even bigger. (smiles) You gotta get out and see more’a the world, pal. I’m heading out. You comin’? As Minna smiles the sun rises behind him and FLARES in ou eyes...clearing into-- INT. TRUMPET PLAYER’S APARTMENT - HARLEM - MORNING 96 SUNLIGHT BEHIND A SMOOTH HEAD. A trumpet playing soft...noodling around a melody. LIONEL’s EYES blinking at...Minna!? He wakes up...the hat spilling off his face...MINNA’S HAT... and sits up and th MUSIC STOPS. He looks over at... THE TRUMPET PLAYER...sitting in the window sill by the fi escape, watching him and smoking a joint. After a beat...

dialogues.speaker: TRUMPET
dialogues.text: Sarge is a good man...but you gotta watch it round a man’s family...you know?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Sarge?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMPET
dialogues.text: Billy. How you think his arm got so fucked up? Colored Marine unit. Carrying ammo ‘til he picked up a gun and helped stop some Jap suicide attack. Got hit though. Some shit, man...he used to really play too. Trombone. Jammed with us at Minton’s a lot in ‘40. He was tight. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revisions 92.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMPET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Came back from the war sour as hell. I told him switch to trumpet...said I’d get him a left- hander made. Said he lost his mojo. Got himself a club. Lionel’s head is clearing...he’s remembering and wants to know things...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You ever meet his wife?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMPET
dialogues.text: Nah, Sarge never married.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Laura’s mother...?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMPET
dialogues.text: I don’t know about any of that. It was always just him and Laura, she was just a little thing hanging out in the kitchen and reading while we played. (beat - regards him) Where you learn to scat like that? (Lionel twitches, he nods ) I got a head like that too. Boiling all the time, turning things over and around. That’s jazz...runs you more’n you run it when it gets up in you. Jazz just a way to make it sound fun...it’s a brain affliction all the same.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You’re lucky. You got a horn to hide behind.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMPET
dialogues.text: Lotta other hours in the day though, you know what I’m sayin’? Too many. He tokes. Lionel nods and they let that sit between them. Lionel stands and scribbles a number on a matchbook.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I’m Lionel. You ever need a ride anywhere...give me a call. TRUMPET PLAYER takes it and smiles as Lionel exits.  97 Pink Revisions

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel is heading across the street to the steps when he sees...Gabby Horowitz...coming down them. He stops...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Mrs. Horowitz...? She looks up...he extends his hand. LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) Jacob Gleason, reporter with the Post... She looks at him quizzically

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: I know Jake very well so I’m not sure who... Caught he switches it up mid-sentence...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Sorry, Jake, brought me to the Hamilton Housing hearing. (extends a hand) Name’s Lionel Cook...Lies in a cook book!...I’m sorry, I’m not trying to be funny. I have a condition. She doesn’t know what to make of this but he’s twitching too and seems sincere... LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) I’m a new writer for the Times and I’m very interested in this story. She shakes his hand...not totally convinced yet. LIONEL (cont'd) (CONT'D) I met your secr-- your aide, Laura Rose. Rose is a rose! She gave me a very illuminating tour of what’s going on in Ft. Greene. I wanted to follow up with her... This piques Gabby’s interest... 93. 97  Pink Revisions 94,

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Really. I thought being the press office for the Borough Authority was more the business of the Times than exposing them. Seeing as your publisher is an investor in the bank that gets to float the Authority’s bonds at preferred rates. Lionel is flummoxed. Smiles big...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I’m not saying I can get it A-1l but if I don’t do the legwork, I can’t try can I? This seems to impress her enough...

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Well, someone's going to win a Pulitzer off Title 1, so maybe ambition will beat greed.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s a big ‘if’. Laura’s gone ahead to the protest, you can come with me if you want. She looks at him and as they walk to the curb we CUT TO: INT GABBY’S CAR/EXT. TRAFFIC JAM - DAY - DRIVING 98 Traffic snarl...they creep along with Gabby at the wheel. He’s trying not to tic too much but she’s eyeing him...

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: A condition you say? What do they call it, if you don’t mind me asking?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Never found anyone who could tell me.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Was that you getting chucked out of the hearing with my friend Paul?  She snaps Pink Revisions 95.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Paul’s a Hammy Hot Head! Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
